msIdentifier.repository: Gonville and Caius College, Lower Library
msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 190/223

summary.seg: John Arderne, Liber receptorum medicinalium, and miscellaneous medical texts (15th century) preceded by a libellus containing anatomical images and texts (c. 1200)

A colophon tells us that the bulk of this manuscript — two popular texts by the English surgeon John Arderne (1307-92) known as the Liber receptorum medicinalium (ff. 7r-43v) and the Practica of fistula in ano (ff. 50r-90v) — was copied in the mid-fifteenth century at the Premonstratensian Abbey of Hagnaby in Lincolnshire. John Welles, scribe, writes that he finished copying the first Arderne treatise (which he calls the Experimenta [experiments]) in 1440, and additional medical texts, recipes and charms in Latin, Dutch and English were added, including a treatise on bloodletting by Ricardus Anglicus (ff. 92r-96v) and an incomplete commentary on Constantinus Africanus’s Viaticum (ff. 102r-109v). The Arderne texts were especially common in fifteenth-century English medical compendia, providing advice and recipes for treating common ailments. The fistula in ano treatise focuses on how to eliminate painful anal fistula and is well-known today for the illustrations that Arderne himself devised to accompany his writings. The manuscript also notably includes a discrete parchment libellus (a small booklet) of three bifolia containing anatomical images that dates to c. 1200 (ff. 1r-6v).

While the Arderne and other texts reveal the usefulness of such practical medical writings to the fifteenth-century canons of Hagnaby, the origin and inclusion of the anatomical libellus present a greater mystery. The nine full-page images are among the earliest anatomical figures in Western Europe, representations of Galen’s nine systems of the body (veins, arteries, bones, nerves, muscles, male reproductive system, stomach and abdominal organs, female reproductive system and brain and ocular system). Each system is drawn on its own folio with relevant descriptive pseudo-Galenic text and captions surrounding or within the diagrams themselves. This is the second appearance of the first five diagrams—known as the Five-Figure Series—featuring squatting human figures upon which the veins, arteries, bones, nerves and muscles are patterned (the earliest instance is in Munich, Bayerische Staatabibliothek, Clm 13002 [c. 1165]). It is the first time the second four diagrams, which feature up-close, abstracted representations of organs, appear. This libellus was likely the exemplar for Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 399, which also contains all nine images.

Hagnaby Abbey did not exist when the libellus was created, and so the place of its creation remains unknown. But either the canons at Hagnaby or a subsequent owner combined the anatomical libellus with the Arderne and other medical writings, sewing them together into a leather wallet to create a kind of encyclopaedia of medical knowledge. The manuscript eventually found its way into the hands of William Moore, a fellow of Gonville and Caius College between 1615-47 and collector of medical and astrological manuscripts, who donated his collection to the college.

Dr Taylor McCall
Managing Editor, Speculum: A Journal of Medieval Studies
The Medieval Academy of America

Peter Murray Jones provides a full collation and description of the contents in 'Experimenta: compilation and construction in two medieval books', Poetica: An International Journal of Linguistic-Literary Studies 91&92 (2019): 61-80, on pp. 76-77 (Appendix).

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos. Two stubbs of excised parchment: the stubb after the last leaf of quire 7 numbered 102[a], and the stubb before the first leaf of quire 8 numbered 101a.

collation.p:
Collection of 8 quires. Quires 1 and 8 parchment, quires 2-7 with the outer and innermost bifolia of each quire parchment, the intervening sheets folded paper or occasionally parchment. The relationship of quires 7 and 8 unclear, possibly formed just one quire at some point with the stubb numbered 102[a] (end of quire 7) wrapping around quire 8. [Note from Cockerell Bindery 1987: Seven gatherings sewn to cover with two groups of stitches.]
Quire 16 (ff. 1-6) |
Quire 224 (ff. 7-30: 3 outer- and the innermost sheets parchment, sheets 4-11 paper)
Quire 316 (ff. 31-46: sheets 1-3 and 7-8 parchment, sheets 4-6 paper)
Quire 416+2 (ff. 47-64: bifolium (ff. 48-49) added after 1st leaf of the quire (f. 47), 1st, the added and the innermost sheets parchment; sheets 3-8 paper)
Quire 518 (ff. 65-82: outer- and innermost sheets parchment; sheets 2-8 paper)
Quire 616 (ff. 83-98: outer- and innermost sheets parchment; sheets 2-7 paper)
Quire 74-1 (ff. 99-101, 102[a]: 4th leaf cancelled, with stub remaining (numbered 102[a] in pencil) |
Quire 810-1 (ff. 101a, 102-110: 1st leaf cancelled, with stub remaining (f. 101a)

supportDesc.condition: Dark parchment, with some cockling. Paper rather soft and damaged at edges. Text faint in places, some mildew.

binding.p: Limp leather wrapper of thick skin, with flap, extending from right edge. Red stains on the inside of the fold-over flap and centre of left portion of cover, suggesting presence of former metal fastenings.
Sewing: Two groups of stitches, a number of strands of thin 2 ply thread, cut lose from quires but still in place on leather wrapper.
Buckram covered box made by Cockerell Bindery, October 1987.
Recycled secondary binding from a much older manuscript, possibly Carolingian, but most likely a Romanesque chemise binding, tunnel sewing visible in the upper inside of the left and right cover.

provenance.p: William Fawn of SkendlebyFawn, William, of Skendleby, presumably a former owner: his name inscribed on ff. 92r and 106r, probably in the 2nd half of 15th century. Skendleby is a small village in the south Lincolnshire Wolds.
Robarte SkateSkate, Robert, presumably a former owner: his name inscribed twice on f. 100v, probably in the 16th century.

history.acquisition: Given by William Moore (1590–1659) Moore, William, 1590-1659 (Venn, ACAD MR606W2): no. 1107 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697). (See Pouzet, 'Observations' (2017).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Montague Rhodes James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, 2 vols. (Cambridge, 1907-1908) vol. 1, pp. 218-19. Robinson, Dated and Datable, no. 240 (pl. 233).

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 190/223, ff. 1-6

msItem.title: Medical notes, diagrams and recipes
msItem.note: Added perhaps on a former wrapper. Written with several 14th(?) century hands.

msItem.title: Anatomical diagrams
msItem.incipit: 2r Incipit hic incisionis sicut Galienus incidit et descripsit
msItem.note: Similar series of illustrations in Oxford, MS. Ashmole 399, ff. 18v-24v (see O'Neill, 1977)

supportDesc.condition: Lower right corner excised with loss of text on f. 1r. Upper and lower edges trimmed with minor losses to images.

layout.seg: Pricking for line-ruling of 48 lines and 2 columns visible in the outer and lower margins, but pages not ruled. Text written without ruling, in the spaces left available from the diagrams, disregarding the pricked area.

decoNote.p: ff. 2r-4r: Five full page anatomical diagrams of male figures (s.c. 'Five-Figure Series' or 'Fünfbilderserie').
ff. 4v-6r: Full page diagrams of male reproductive system, internal organs, female reproductive system, and eyes and brain.
The diagrams on ff. 2r-6r appear often together as a set of images known as the 'Nine-System Figure Series' (See T. McCall (2016) 1-22).

ff. 6v: A diagram illustrative of the connections between the four classical elements (fire, air, water, earth) with Aristotelian (dry, humid, hot, cold) and Platonic (mobile/immobile, thin/stout, and sharp/blunt) properties, including a sketch of the numeric elements of Platonic Lambda diagram.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 190/223, ff. 7-101

msItem.title: Liber receptorum medicinalium
msItem.author: John Arderne
msItem.incipit: 7r Ad cancrum in virga viris sive in umbilico
msItem.colophon: 43v Expliciunt experimenta magister Iohannes Arderne secundum diuersos doctores quibus ipsemet Iohannes usus est et vtilia nimis invenit ac posteris caritatiue scripta reliquid quod Frater Iohannes Welles Canonicus de Hagneby qui scripsit ista anno domini mo cccco xlo quando venit de curia Romana ipso anno quartanam paciebatur per vii menses. Deo gracias.
msItem.note: On top margin f. 7r, Invocation "Ihesus Maria Assit principio sancta maria virgo".

msItem.title: Pilosella, Mouse eare
msItem.note: Added bifolium containing 16th-century extracts from a herbal, inserted after the first leaf of quire 4.

msItem.title: Practica chirurgiae
msItem.author: John Arderne
msItem.incipit: 50r Ego Iohannes Arderne de Newarke predictus a prima pestilentia
msItem.finalRubric: 91v Explicit practica cirurgie magistri Iohannis Arderne de Newwork'

msItem.title: On bloodletting
msItem.author: Ricardus Anglicus
msItem.explicit: 96v Et hec sufficiunt de flebotomia et ventosus. Explicit.

msItem.title: On bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 96v Discretionis inspiciendi sanguinem triplex est modus
msItem.finalRubric: 97v Explicit considerationes de inspeccione sanguinis etc.

msItem.title: On bloodletting
msItem.author: Petrus Hispanus
msItem.incipit: 97v Note bene de flebotomia secundum magistrum P Iuliani si necessitas fuerit in omni tempore
msItem.explicit: 98r sanguinem minuerit numquam febere habebis. Explicit.

msItem.incipit: 98r Medicamen bonum et probatum ad plagam seu carnes uel rupturas subite

msItem.title: Viaticum (excerpt)
msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus
msItem.rubric: 98v De ruptura ciphac Constantinus in Viatico

msItem.title: Note on red lead, a diuretic powder, pestilential swelling
msItem.incipit: 99v De serusa uel gersa que fit de serpentaria
msItem.explicit: 100r et post sanantia ut decet etc.

msItem.title: Added recipes
msItem.note: Various added recipes written in 15th- and 16th century hands.

supportDesc.support: Parchment (HFFH) and paper. Watermark 1: ff. 10/27, 11/26, 12/25, 17/20, 34/43 Cloche très allongée ( 65 30 ) Located horizontally in the centre of the folded sheet; simliar to Briquet 3971-84 (dated between 1396-1468, Italy) Watermark 2: ff. 51/62, 53/60, 55/58, 68/79, 71/76, 85/96, 86/95. A majuscule latin A topped with a single-line cross ending in spheres ( 50 30 ) Located horizontally in the centre of the folded sheets; similar to Briquet 7900-7904 (dated between 1385-1442, Southern France/Northern Italy).

collation.p:
Collection of 6 quires, the outer and innermost bifolia of each quire parchment, the intervening sheets folded paper or occasionally parchment. The stubb at the end of quire 7 might have wrapped around quire 8 at some point.
Quire 224 (ff. 7-30): 3 outer and the inner most sheet parchment, sheets 4-11 paper
Quire 316 (ff. 31-46): sheets 1-3 and 7-8 parchment, sheets 4-6 paper
Quire 416+2 (ff. 47-64): bifolium (ff. 48-49) added after 1st leaf of the quire (f. 47), 1st, the added and the innermost sheets parchment; sheets 3-8 paper
Quire 518 (ff. 65-82): outer- and the innermost sheets parchment; sheets 2-8 paper
Quire 616 (ff. 83-98): outer- and the innermost sheets parchment; sheets 2-7 paper
Quire 74-1 (ff. 99-101, 102[a]: 4th leaf cancelled, with stub remaining (numbered 102[a] in pencil)

signatures.p: Red alphabets A-F (quires 2-7) centered on the upper margin of each verso, with Arabic numeral running in folio sequence on the upper margin of each recto. The first folio of each quire has the quire letter and number 1 (except for quire 4 that begins with an originally blank first folio and an added bifolium, C.I written on the 4th leaf.

supportDesc.condition: Leaves quite dirty and at times worn out; ff. 7 and 47 have incised outer margin.

layout.seg: Ruled in brown ink, frame only. 36-40 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Scribe John Welles Welles, John writing in English cursive.
Multiple short additions in variations of English secretary script.

decoNote.p: Manicule and line-drawn instruments and body parts in the margins.

origin.p: Written in 1440 by Canon John Welles of Hagnaby Abbey Hagnaby Abbey: '... quod Frater Johannes Well' Canonicus de Hagneby qui Scripsit ista anno domini mo cccco xlo quando venit de curia Romana...' (inscription on f. 43v).

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 190/223, ff. 102-110v

msItem.title: Added recipes
msItem.note: Various added recipes written in 15th century hands.

collation.p: First leaf excised, possibly part of a former wrapper that became obsolete when the quire was appended to the end.

list.item: Quire 810-1 (ff. 101a, 102-110: 1st leaf cancelled, with stub remaining (f. 101a)

supportDesc.condition: Lower outer corner of f. 109 has a curved incision.

layout.seg: In single columns, 39 lines to the page. Line- and frame-ruled in ink, pricking occasionally visible in the outer margin. Written below top line.

handNote.p: One main hand writing in English secretary script.

change.persName: Tuija Ainonen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
